ACTION AGAINST A COMEDIAN,
Av the Southwark County Cou:t, on Monday morn.
ing, before his Honour dudge Holroyd, the case of
PDidcott v. Macdermots waz heard, Mr, Arnistrong,
volicitor, appeared for the plaintiff, whe, he sai
was a musical and dramatic agent. Defendant was |

a comedian and vocalist, and was also an agent, and
the action was brought agains) him to recover the
sum of £35 lls. Si, beivs commission due npon
engagements precured for him by the plaintiff. The
first item was comwmissicu at five per cent. up2n Myr,
Macdermoit's engsgenw nt at tho Londen Pavilion at
£20 per week, on whica engagement there were
twenty-three weol.s’ commission due up to July 20:h,
Then ihere was c.mmission at Sve per cent. upow
Mr. Macdermott’s engagements at the Cambridge
Muric Falla. £15 perweek, aud at Colling’s at £22 125,
per week; upon two engagements st E NMaburgh and
Newcastle at £30 per week; and_aé the Star, in
Pablia, ab £40 per week. Mr. R. Andrews, the
plaintii's ¢l was called to prove the claim, and
producid the contracts is respect of which the action
was brought. The def ndant siid he was quite pre-
pared to pay the plaintiff £24 1s, Sd.,and had brought
cheque wish him for that sam, Ho said he objected
to pay commission upon all re evgagements, Not only
was that unusual, bot—~ His Honour: Inever saw
an engagement upon which there was not commission
payable upon re-engagements, Mr. Armstrong: Mr.
Dideott mace this man. He wes nobody before Mr,
Didesti rook him up, The Defendant (excitedly) :
Tt was Macdermott before Mr. Didcott ever came
into the business. Mr. Armstrong: You are
an agent yourself? Defendant: No, Fam nob an
agent. Mr, Armstrong: What does “Macdermott’s
Universal Dramatic sad Musical Agency ’’ mean,
then? Defendans: That is my brother, Edward
Maedermott. Mr. Armstrong: Don’t you know that
the wsuel commistion is ten per cent? Defendant;
Not with a man of my reputation. Big turns like
myself pay five por cent, His honour remarked that
wheres man put his hand co a certain document, and
that documert was brought into court, he could not:

goaway from it. Ho gave judgment for the pisintiff
for the amount claimed, ‘Phe defendant offered to
hand over his cheque for 2413. 8.1, Mx, Armstrong ;
We would rather not take ais chequo, sir, Defen-
dant (excitedly): He has borrowed money of me and
ray family. Ihave been brought here to be insulted.
Mr. Didcott: He has said he is not anagent, I shall
be able to prova right up to the hilt that he is an
agent. The parties then lef: the court.
